qas.question: Along with the Dominicans, what mendicant order was founded in the 13th century?
What notable vow was sworn by the mendicant orders?
How did the mendicant orders make a living?
What was the crusade against the Cathars called?
Along with the Cathars and Humiliati, what group was notably condemned as heretics in this period?

context: In the 13th century mendicant orders—the <a0_0>Franciscans<a0_0/> and the Dominicans—who swore vows of <a1_0>poverty<a1_0/> and earned their living by <a2_0>begging<a2_0/>, were approved by the papacy. Religious groups such as <a4_0>the Waldensians<a4_0/> and the Humiliati also attempted to return to the life of early Christianity in the middle 12th and early 13th centuries, but they were condemned as heretical by the papacy. Others joined the Cathars, another heretical movement condemned by the papacy. In 1209, a crusade was preached against the Cathars, <a3_0>the Albigensian Crusade<a3_0/>, which in combination with the medieval Inquisition, eliminated them.
